why-github-matters.title: Why GitHub Matters for Your Career
why-github-matters.intro: Your GitHub profile is your developer portfolio. It's where recruiters go to verify your skills, see how you think, and determine if you're worth interviewing. Let's look at what makes GitHub so important.

sections.heading: The Recruiter's 30-Second Scan
sections.content:
Here's exactly what a recruiter does when they get your resume:

1. **Scan resume** (6-7 seconds)
2. **Click GitHub link** (if it looks promising)
3. **Check profile photo and bio** - "Is this person real and professional?"
4. **Glance at pinned repos** - "Do they have relevant projects?"
5. **Click on one repo** - "Can I understand what this is?"
6. **Decision made** - Interview or pass

**Real example of what they see:**

‚ùå **Instant rejection:**
- No profile photo (default gray avatar)
- Bio: empty
- Pinned repos: "my-first-react-app", "tutorial-follow-along"
- No README in top repo

‚úÖ **Gets the interview:**
- Professional headshot
- Bio: "Full-Stack Developer | React, Node.js, PostgreSQL | Building tools for small businesses"
- Pinned repos: "inventory-tracker", "customer-portal", "scheduling-api"
- Clean README with screenshots

sections.heading: What GitHub Shows That Resumes Can't
sections.content:
Your resume says "Built a full-stack e-commerce platform."

Your GitHub PROVES it by showing:

**Code organization:**
```
/src
  /components
    /Cart
      Cart.tsx
      CartItem.tsx
      CartSummary.tsx
    /Products
      ProductList.tsx
      ProductCard.tsx
  /hooks
    useCart.ts
    useProducts.ts
  /services
    api.ts
    stripe.ts
```

**Commit messages:**
```
feat: add guest checkout flow
fix: resolve cart total calculation bug
refactor: extract payment logic into service
```

**Documentation quality:**
- Clear README explaining the project
- Screenshots of the UI
- Instructions someone could actually follow

A resume is a claim. GitHub is evidence.

sections.heading: Real Talk: What Recruiters Notice First
sections.content:
I surveyed 15 tech recruiters. Here's what they said:

**"I check if the profile photo looks professional."** - 12/15 recruiters

**"I only look at pinned repos. If there's nothing pinned, I leave."** - 9/15 recruiters

**"I click on one project and scroll the README for 10 seconds."** - 11/15 recruiters

**"If there's no README, I assume they can't communicate."** - 14/15 recruiters

**"I look for projects similar to what we build."** - 13/15 recruiters

**The takeaway:** You have about 30 seconds. Optimize for that.

sections.heading: GitHub at Each Hiring Stage
sections.content:
Your GitHub gets checked multiple times:

**Application Review:**
> Recruiter thinks: "Resume says 3 years React experience. Let me verify..."
> *Checks GitHub, sees 5 React projects with clean code*
> "Okay, this checks out. Moving to phone screen."

**Phone Screen:**
> Recruiter: "I saw your recipe app on GitHub. Tell me about the biggest challenge you faced building it."
> *If you can't discuss your own code, red flag*

**Technical Interview:**
> Engineer: "I noticed you used Redux in your e-commerce project. Why not Context API?"
> *They've read your code. Be ready to defend choices.*

**Final Decision:**
> Hiring manager comparing two similar candidates:
> Candidate A: Basic GitHub, tutorial projects
> Candidate B: Polished projects, excellent documentation
> *B gets the offer*

optimize-for-recruiters.title: Optimize for Recruiters, Not Developers
optimize-for-recruiters.intro: Here's a truth that changes everything: the person reviewing your GitHub probably can't code. Technical recruiters understand tech concepts, but they're not reading your actual code. They're looking for signals that you're worth passing to the engineering team.

sections.heading: The Same Project, Two Different READMEs
sections.content:
Let's look at how a developer might describe their project vs. how a recruiter needs to see it:

‚ùå **Written for developers:**
```markdown
# Recipe App

Built with CRA. Uses Redux for state management 
with redux-thunk for async actions. REST API built 
with Express, Sequelize ORM, PostgreSQL. 
Authentication via Passport.js with JWT strategy.

## Installation
npm install && npm start
```

‚úÖ **Written for recruiters:**
```markdown
# Mince - Recipe Discovery App

![Demo](./demo.gif)

A web application that helps home cooks find recipes 
based on ingredients they already have. Search 5,000+ 
recipes, save favorites, and generate shopping lists.

## Built With
- **Frontend:** React, Redux, Tailwind CSS
- **Backend:** Node.js, Express, PostgreSQL
- **Auth:** JWT-based user authentication

## Key Features
- Search recipes by multiple ingredients
- User accounts with saved favorites
- Auto-generated shopping lists
- Mobile-responsive design
```

Same project. One gets interviews, one doesn't.

sections.heading: Technical Jargon: A Before/After Guide
sections.content:
Here's how to translate developer-speak into recruiter-friendly language:

| Developer Version | Recruiter-Friendly Version |
|------------------|---------------------------|
| "Implemented Redux middleware for optimistic UI updates" | "App updates instantly when users take actions, making it feel fast and responsive" |
| "Used Sequelize ORM with PostgreSQL" | "Database stores user data securely using PostgreSQL" |
| "REST API with Express" | "Backend server handles user requests and data" |
| "Deployed with Docker on AWS EC2" | "Live and accessible on the web 24/7" |
| "Implemented debouncing on search input" | "Search results appear as you type without lag" |
| "Used CSS Grid and Flexbox" | "Works on phones, tablets, and desktop" |

**The rule:** If your mom wouldn't understand it, explain it differently.

sections.heading: Structure Your README for Skimming
sections.content:
Recruiters skim. They don't read. Here's the structure that works:

```markdown
# Project Name
![Screenshot or GIF - FIRST THING THEY SEE]

One sentence explaining what this does for users.

## Demo
[Live Demo](https://your-app.com) | [Video Walkthrough](https://youtube.com/...)

## Features
- Feature 1 (what users can do)
- Feature 2 (what users can do)
- Feature 3 (what users can do)

## Built With
- Frontend: React, TypeScript, Tailwind
- Backend: Node.js, Express, PostgreSQL
- APIs: Stripe, SendGrid

## Screenshots
[More visuals here]

## Getting Started
[Setup instructions]

## Contact
Your Name - [LinkedIn](url) - email@example.com
```

**Key principles:**
- Visual first (screenshot or GIF at top)
- What it does before how it's built
- Bullet points over paragraphs
- Bold the important stuff

sections.heading: Power Words That Get Interviews
sections.content:
Certain words trigger positive responses from recruiters:

**Action verbs (use these):**
- Built, Developed, Created, Engineered
- Implemented, Integrated, Deployed
- Designed, Architected, Structured
- Optimized, Improved, Enhanced

**Before/After examples:**

‚ùå "Made a thing that gets data from an API"
‚úÖ "Built a real-time dashboard that displays live cryptocurrency prices"

‚ùå "Used React and stuff"
‚úÖ "Developed a responsive React application with TypeScript"

‚ùå "It has a database"
‚úÖ "Engineered a PostgreSQL database schema supporting 10,000+ user records"

‚ùå "Login works"
‚úÖ "Implemented secure JWT authentication with password reset flow"

**Numbers are powerful:**
- "Processes 5,000+ recipes"
- "Handles 100+ concurrent users"
- "Reduced load time by 40%"
- "97% test coverage"

sections.heading: The 10-Second Test
sections.content:
Try this on your own README:

1. Open your project README
2. Set a 10-second timer
3. Scroll through the page
4. Stop and ask yourself:

**Could you answer these questions?**
- What does this project do?
- What technologies were used?
- Is there a live demo?
- Does it look professional?

**If you can't answer all four in 10 seconds**, your README needs work.

**Quick fixes:**
- Add a screenshot at the very top
- Write a one-sentence description
- Add clear "Built With" section
- Add demo link prominently

profile-setup.title: Setting Up a Professional Profile
profile-setup.intro: Your GitHub profile is the landing page of your developer portfolio. Let's set it up step by step with real examples of what works.

sections.heading: Profile Photo: What Works
sections.content:
Your profile photo is the first thing people see.

**Good profile photos:**
- Clear headshot, shoulders up
- Good lighting (natural light works best)
- Simple background (solid color or blurred)
- Professional but approachable expression
- Same photo you'd use on LinkedIn

**Bad profile photos:**
- Default GitHub avatar (gray geometric pattern)
- Cartoon/anime characters (unless you're established)
- Group photos or distant shots
- Logos (you're a person, not a brand)
- Poor lighting or blurry images

**Pro tip:** Use the same photo across GitHub, LinkedIn, and your portfolio. Recruiters check multiple platforms‚Äîhelp them recognize you.

sections.heading: Bio Examples That Work
sections.content:
Your bio appears right under your name. You get about 160 characters. Here are real examples:

**For job seekers:**
```
Full-Stack Developer | React, Node.js, PostgreSQL | 
Building tools that make developers' lives easier | 
Open to new opportunities
```

**For bootcamp grads:**
```
Software Engineer | Recent grad from [Bootcamp] | 
Passionate about accessible web design | 
Looking for my first role
```

**For career changers:**
```
Former teacher ‚Üí Software Developer | Python, Django | 
I bring communication skills to technical teams | 
Seeking junior roles
```

**For students:**
```
CS Student @ [University] | Java, Python, React | 
Expected graduation May 2025 | 
Looking for internships
```

**The formula:**
`[Role] | [Top 2-3 Technologies] | [What you're about] | [Current status]`

sections.heading: How to Pin the Right Repositories
sections.content:
You can pin 6 repositories. Here's the strategy:

**Step 1: Click "Customize your pins" on your profile**

**Step 2: Choose strategically:**

| Slot | What to Pin | Why |
|------|-------------|-----|
| 1 | Your absolute best project | Gets the most clicks |
| 2 | Most relevant to target jobs | Shows you're a fit |
| 3 | Different tech stack | Shows range |
| 4 | Something unique/interesting | Memorable |
| 5-6 | Strong backups or open source | Extra credibility |

**What NOT to pin:**
- `tutorial-project` (obviously followed a guide)
- `my-first-react-app` (screams beginner)
- Forks with no contributions
- Projects with no README
- Incomplete projects (unless clearly marked)

**Example good set:**
1. `inventory-management-system` - Full-stack CRUD app
2. `weather-dashboard` - API integration project
3. `python-data-analysis` - Different language
4. `browser-extension` - Unique project type
5. `open-source-contribution` - Shows collaboration
6. `algorithm-solutions` - Shows CS fundamentals

sections.heading: Creating Your Profile README
sections.content:
GitHub has a secret feature: create a repo with YOUR username, and its README shows on your profile.

**Setup:**
1. Create new repository named exactly your username (e.g., `johndoe/johndoe`)
2. Check "Add a README file"
3. Edit the README.md

**Simple but effective template:**
```markdown
# Hi, I'm [Your Name] üëã

üéØ Full-Stack Developer focused on React and Node.js

üî≠ Currently working on: [Current Project]

üå± Learning: TypeScript, AWS

üíº Open to: Full-time opportunities

sections.heading: Complete Profile Checklist
sections.content:
Use this checklist to ensure your profile is ready:

**Profile basics:**
- [ ] Professional headshot photo
- [ ] Name matches your resume
- [ ] Bio with role, technologies, status
- [ ] Location (city is enough)
- [ ] Email address visible

**Pinned repositories:**

- [ ] Each has a clear description

**Profile README:**

readme-structure.title: README Structure: Table of Contents & General Info
readme-structure.intro: A README is often the only part of your project a recruiter reads. Let's build one that gets you interviews, section by section.

sections.heading: The Anatomy of a Great README
sections.content:
Here's the structure that works:

```markdown
# Project Name

![Screenshot](./screenshot.png)

One-sentence description of what this does.

## Table of Contents
- [About](#about)
- [Demo](#demo)
- [Features](#features)
- [Built With](#built-with)
- [Getting Started](#getting-started)
- [Usage](#usage)
- [Contact](#contact)

## About
[2-3 sentences about the project]

## Demo
[Links and visuals]

## Features
[Bullet list]

## Built With
[Technology list]

## Getting Started
[Setup instructions]

## Usage
[How to use it]

## Contact
[Your info]
```

**Why this order?**
- Visual first (screenshot catches attention)
- What it does before how it's built
- Table of Contents shows scope
- Technical details come later

sections.heading: Building Your Table of Contents
sections.content:
A clickable Table of Contents makes long READMEs navigable.

**Here's how to make links work:**

```markdown
## Table of Contents
- [About](#about)
- [Demo](#demo)
- [Features](#features)
- [Built With](#built-with)
- [Getting Started](#getting-started)
- [Usage](#usage)
- [Contact](#contact)
```

**The linking rules:**
- `#about` links to `## About`
- `#built-with` links to `## Built With` (spaces become dashes)
- `#getting-started` links to `## Getting Started`

**Pro tip:** Write your Table of Contents LAST, after you've finalized all sections. That way your links are accurate.

**When to skip it:**
- If your README is short (under 200 lines)
- If you only have 3-4 sections

For substantial projects, it's always worth including.

sections.heading: Writing the About Section
sections.content:
The About (or General Info) section is your elevator pitch.

**Bad example:**
```markdown
## About
This is a project I made for my bootcamp. It uses 
React and has a backend.
```

**Good example:**
```markdown
## About

Mince is a recipe discovery app that helps home cooks 
find meals based on ingredients they already have.

**The problem:** I was throwing away food every week 
because I'd buy ingredients for recipes, use half, 
and forget the rest.

**The solution:** Input what's in your fridge, get 
recipes that use those ingredients. No more waste.

Built as my capstone project at [Bootcamp], this app 
demonstrates full-stack development with React, Node.js, 
and PostgreSQL.
```

**The formula:**
1. What it does (one sentence)
2. The problem it solves
3. Why you built it (personal connection)
4. Context (bootcamp project, side project, etc.)

sections.heading: Making It Personal (Without Oversharing)
sections.content:
Personal stories make projects memorable. Here are examples:

**Recipe app:**
> I built this after realizing I was throwing away $50 of groceries every week. As someone trying to save money, this was unacceptable.

**Fitness tracker:**
> After my doctor told me to exercise more, I wanted an app that made tracking workouts actually enjoyable.

**Study flashcards:**
> I used to make physical flashcards for every exam. I wanted to bring that experience online with spaced repetition.

**Budget app:**
> Moving to a new city, I needed to track every dollar. Existing apps were too complicated‚ÄîI wanted something simple.

**What to share:**
- A specific frustration that led to the project
- A personal goal the project helps achieve
- A problem you or someone you know faced

**What NOT to share:**
- Your life story
- Anything too personal or unrelated
- Complaints about other apps (stay positive)

sections.heading: Formatting for Maximum Impact
sections.content:
Good formatting makes content readable.

**Use short paragraphs:**
```markdown
‚ùå Bad:
This app allows users to search for recipes based on 
ingredients they have at home and it was built using 
React for the frontend and Node.js for the backend 
with PostgreSQL as the database and it features 
user authentication and the ability to save favorites.

‚úÖ Good:
Search for recipes based on ingredients you already have.

Built with React, Node.js, and PostgreSQL.

Features user authentication and saved favorites.
```

**Use markdown formatting:**
- **Bold** for emphasis: `**important**`
- `code` for technical terms: `` `npm install` ``
- > Blockquotes for callouts: `> Note: This requires Node 18+`

**Use visuals:**
```markdown
## About

![App Screenshot](./screenshots/main.png)

Mince helps you cook with what you have...
```

A screenshot at the top of About immediately shows what the project is.

walkthrough-videos.title: Walkthrough Videos That Impress
walkthrough-videos.intro: Recruiters can't run your code. A 60-second video showing your app in action is worth more than 1,000 lines of code they'll never read.

sections.heading: Why Videos Beat Screenshots
sections.content:
**Screenshots show:**
- What your app looks like
- One moment in time
- Static information

**Videos show:**
- How your app actually works
- The flow between features
- Loading states, animations, transitions
- That it actually runs (not just mockups)
- Your attention to detail

**Real talk:** Anyone can screenshot a Figma design. Videos prove you built something real.

sections.heading: Recording Your Walkthrough
sections.content:
**Tools (all free):**
- **Mac:** QuickTime Player (built-in) ‚Üí File ‚Üí New Screen Recording
- **Windows:** Xbox Game Bar (Win+G) or OBS Studio
- **Any platform:** Loom (free tier available)

**Settings:**
- Record at 1080p if possible
- Use a clean browser (no embarrassing bookmarks)
- Close notifications
- Use incognito mode (clean browser state)

**Recording tips:**
1. Practice the flow 2-3 times before recording
2. Move your mouse slowly and deliberately
3. Pause briefly on important screens
4. Keep it under 90 seconds (60 is ideal)

sections.heading: What to Show in Your Video
sections.content:
**Script template (60 seconds):**

```
0-5 sec:   Show the homepage/landing page
5-15 sec:  Sign up or log in (shows auth works)
15-35 sec: Core feature #1 (the main thing your app does)
35-50 sec: Core feature #2 (another impressive feature)
50-60 sec: Any "wow" moment (animation, real-time update, etc.)
```

**What to prioritize:**

‚úÖ Show these:
- User authentication (sign up, log in, log out)
- CRUD operations (create, read, update, delete something)
- Search/filter functionality
- Responsive design (resize the window)
- Real-time features (if any)
- Loading states and error handling

‚ùå Skip these:
- Typing slowly in forms
- Reading through long pages
- Features that don't demonstrate skill
- Anything broken or unfinished

sections.heading: Hosting and Embedding Your Video
sections.content:
**Best option: YouTube (unlisted)**

1. Upload to YouTube
2. Set visibility to "Unlisted" (only people with link can see)
3. Copy the link

**Adding to your README:**

```markdown
## Demo

[![Watch Demo](./thumbnail.png)](https://youtu.be/your-video-id)

Click the image above to watch a 60-second walkthrough.
```

**Or just paste the link:**
```markdown
## Demo

üé¨ [Watch the video walkthrough](https://youtu.be/your-video-id)
```

**Pro tip:** Create a custom thumbnail. Take a screenshot of your app's best screen and add text like "60s Demo" in Canva. Looks way more professional than auto-generated thumbnails.

sections.heading: GIFs for Quick Feature Demos
sections.content:
For individual features, GIFs work great. They play automatically in GitHub.

**When to use GIFs:**
- Single feature (5-15 seconds)
- Inline in README sections
- Showing one specific interaction

**When to use video:**
- Full app walkthrough
- Multiple features
- Anything over 15 seconds

**Creating GIFs:**
- **Mac:** Kap (free, amazing)
- **Windows:** ScreenToGif (free)
- **Convert video to GIF:** ezgif.com

**Keep GIFs small:**
- Under 10MB for fast loading
- 5-15 seconds max
- Reduce dimensions if needed

**Example in README:**
```markdown
## Features

### Real-time Search
![Search Demo](./gifs/search-demo.gif)

Results filter as you type with debounced API calls.
```

technologies-setup.title: Technologies & Setup Instructions
technologies-setup.intro: The Technologies section verifies resume claims. Setup instructions show you can write documentation. Both are non-negotiable for a professional README.

sections.heading: Technology Section Examples
sections.content:
**Simple format (great for most projects):**
```markdown
## Built With

- **Frontend:** React 18, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS
- **Backend:** Node.js, Express
- **Database:** PostgreSQL
- **Auth:** JWT, bcrypt
- **Deployment:** Vercel (frontend), Railway (backend)
```

**With badges (more visual):**
```markdown
## Tech Stack

![React](https://img.shields.io/badge/React-18-61DAFB?logo=react)
![TypeScript](https://img.shields.io/badge/TypeScript-5-3178C6?logo=typescript)
![Node.js](https://img.shields.io/badge/Node.js-18-339933?logo=node.js)
![PostgreSQL](https://img.shields.io/badge/PostgreSQL-15-4169E1?logo=postgresql)
```

**Detailed format (for complex projects):**
```markdown
## Technologies

### Frontend
| Tech | Version | Purpose |
|------|---------|--------|
| React | 18.2 | UI Library |
| TypeScript | 5.0 | Type Safety |
| Tailwind | 3.3 | Styling |
| React Query | 4.0 | Server State |

### Backend
| Tech | Version | Purpose |
|------|---------|--------|
| Node.js | 18 | Runtime |
| Express | 4.18 | Server Framework |
| Prisma | 4.8 | ORM |
```

**Always include versions.** It shows you pay attention to details.

sections.heading: Complete Setup Instructions Template
sections.content:
Here's a template you can copy and customize:

```markdown
## Getting Started

### Prerequisites

Make sure you have installed:
- Node.js 18+ ([download](https://nodejs.org/))
- PostgreSQL 14+ ([download](https://postgresql.org/))
- Git

### Installation

1. **Clone the repository**
   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/yourusername/project-name.git
   cd project-name
   ```

2. **Install dependencies**
   ```bash
   npm install
   ```

3. **Set up environment variables**
   ```bash
   cp .env.example .env
   ```
   Then edit `.env` with your values:
   ```
   DATABASE_URL=postgresql://user:password@localhost:5432/dbname
   JWT_SECRET=your-secret-key
   ```

4. **Set up the database**
   ```bash
   npm run db:setup
   ```

5. **Start the development server**
   ```bash
   npm run dev
   ```

6. **Open your browser**
   Visit `http://localhost:3000`

### Running Tests
```bash
npm test
```
```

**Key elements:**
- Prerequisites with download links
- Numbered steps
- Code blocks for every command
- Environment variable instructions
- Expected result (where to see the app)

sections.heading: The .env.example File
sections.content:
Never commit your actual `.env` file. Always provide a `.env.example`.

**Create `.env.example`:**
```bash
# Database
DATABASE_URL=postgresql://user:password@localhost:5432/yourdb

# Authentication
JWT_SECRET=your-secret-key-here
JWT_EXPIRES_IN=7d

# External APIs
STRIPE_SECRET_KEY=sk_test_xxxxx
SENDGRID_API_KEY=SG.xxxxx

# App Config
NODE_ENV=development
PORT=3000
```

**In your README:**
```markdown
3. **Set up environment variables**
   ```bash
   cp .env.example .env
   ```
   Then edit `.env` and replace placeholder values 
   with your actual credentials.
   
   - `DATABASE_URL`: Your PostgreSQL connection string
   - `JWT_SECRET`: Any random string (use a password generator)
   - `STRIPE_SECRET_KEY`: Get from [Stripe Dashboard](https://stripe.com)
```

**Add `.env` to `.gitignore`:**
```
# .gitignore
.env
.env.local
```

sections.heading: Common Gotchas to Address
sections.content:
**Database not running:**
```markdown
### Troubleshooting

**"Connection refused" error:**
Make sure PostgreSQL is running:
- Mac: `brew services start postgresql`
- Windows: Check Services app for PostgreSQL
- Linux: `sudo systemctl start postgresql`
```

**Node version issues:**
```markdown
**Wrong Node version:**
This project requires Node 18+. Check your version:
```bash
node --version
```
Install the correct version using nvm:
```bash
nvm install 18
nvm use 18
```
```

**Port already in use:**
```markdown
**Port 3000 already in use:**
Kill the process using that port:
```bash
# Mac/Linux
lsof -ti:3000 | xargs kill

# Or just use a different port
PORT=3001 npm run dev
```
```

**Test your own instructions:**
Clone your repo to a new folder and follow your setup instructions from scratch. If anything fails, fix the docs.

code-examples.title: Code Examples That Impress
code-examples.intro: Including code snippets in your README gives recruiters a window into your coding style without digging through files. Here's how to showcase code that makes them want to hire you.

sections.heading: What Code to Feature
sections.content:
**Feature code that shows skill:**

‚úÖ **Good candidates:**
- Clean API endpoints with error handling
- Elegant solutions to tricky problems  
- Well-structured components
- Custom hooks or utilities
- Code that shows design patterns

‚ùå **Skip these:**
- Basic boilerplate (everyone has the same)
- Code that needs 50 lines of context
- Anything over 30 lines
- Code with obvious improvements needed

**The test:** Would you be proud to explain this code in an interview?

If yes, include it. If not, either improve it or find a better example.

app-features.title: Documenting App Features
app-features.intro: The Features section is where you show off what your project can do. Every feature you built represents skills a recruiter is looking for. Don't be modest‚Äîyou built it, own it.

sections.heading: Features Section Examples
sections.content:
**Simple format (works for most projects):**

```markdown
## Features

- User authentication (sign up, log in, password reset)
- Search 5,000+ recipes by ingredient
- Save favorites to your profile
- Generate shopping lists from recipes
- Mobile-responsive design
- Dark/light mode toggle
```

**Detailed format (for impressive projects):**

```markdown
## Features

### User Authentication
Complete auth flow including email signup, social login 
(Google, GitHub), and secure password reset via email.

### Smart Recipe Search
- Search by multiple ingredients
- Filter by cuisine, time, and difficulty
- Results update as you type (debounced)
- Handles 5,000+ recipes with <100ms response time

### Personalization
- Save favorite recipes
- Create custom collections
- Dietary preference filters
- Recently viewed history

### Shopping List
- Auto-generate from selected recipes
- Combine duplicate ingredients
- Check off items as you shop
- Share list via link
```

sections.heading: Turning Simple Features Into Impressive Ones
sections.content:
Most features sound basic. Here's how to make them impressive:

| Basic Description | Impressive Description |
|------------------|----------------------|
| "Has a search bar" | "Real-time search with debouncing and instant results" |
| "Users can log in" | "JWT authentication with secure HTTP-only cookies and refresh tokens" |
| "Works on mobile" | "Mobile-first responsive design with touch-optimized interactions" |
| "Shows a list of items" | "Virtualized list rendering 1,000+ items without performance lag" |
| "Has a form" | "Multi-step form with validation, error handling, and draft saving" |
| "Sends emails" | "Automated email notifications using SendGrid with retry logic" |
| "Connects to database" | "PostgreSQL database with optimized queries and connection pooling" |

**The pattern:** Basic feature + technical detail + benefit

sections.heading: Features With Visuals
sections.content:
Pair features with GIFs or screenshots:

```markdown
## Features

### Real-time Search
![Search Demo](./gifs/search.gif)

Results filter instantly as you type. Uses debouncing 
to minimize API calls while maintaining responsiveness.

### Drag & Drop Organization
![Drag Demo](./gifs/drag-drop.gif)

Reorder your recipe collections with intuitive 
drag-and-drop. Changes save automatically.

### Dark Mode
| Light Mode | Dark Mode |
|------------|----------|
| ![Light](./screenshots/light.png) | ![Dark](./screenshots/dark.png) |

System preference detection with manual override. 
Settings persist across sessions.
```

**Why visuals matter:**
- Prove the feature actually works
- Catch attention while scrolling
- Show polish and attention to detail

sections.heading: Current vs. Planned Features
sections.content:
It's okay to show roadmap items‚Äîjust be clear about status:

```markdown
## Features

### Implemented ‚úÖ
- User authentication
- Recipe search and filtering
- Favorites and collections
- Shopping list generation
- Responsive design

### In Progress üöß
- Social sharing
- Meal planning calendar

### Planned üìã
- Grocery delivery integration
- Nutrition information
- Recipe recommendations based on history
```

**Why show planned features:**
- Shows you think about product growth
- Provides interview conversation topics
- Demonstrates ongoing commitment

**Rules:**
- Completed features should significantly outweigh planned
- Don't list things you'll never actually build
- Update as you complete items

sections.heading: Connecting Features to Skills
sections.content:
Help recruiters understand what each feature demonstrates:

```markdown
## Technical Highlights

| Feature | Skills Demonstrated |
|---------|--------------------|
| User Auth | Security, session management, form validation |
| Recipe Search | API integration, state management, UX optimization |
| Shopping List | Data structures, local storage, real-time sync |
| Responsive Design | CSS, mobile-first development, accessibility |
| Performance | Caching, lazy loading, query optimization |
```

**Or inline:**

```markdown
### Smart Recipe Search
*Demonstrates: API integration, debouncing, state management*

Search 5,000+ recipes with real-time filtering...
```

**This helps recruiters who are specifically looking for certain skills quickly find evidence of them.**

keyTakeaways: List every feature‚Äîeach demonstrates skills you've developed
Transform basic descriptions: feature + technical detail + benefit
Pair features with GIFs or screenshots to prove they work
Clearly distinguish completed vs. planned features
Connect features to skills recruiters are looking for

pinning-projects.title: Pinning Your Best Projects
pinning-projects.intro: GitHub lets you pin up to 6 repositories to your profile. These are the first projects recruiters see‚Äîchoose strategically.

sections.heading: How to Pin Repositories
sections.content:
**Step by step:**

1. Go to your GitHub profile (github.com/yourusername)
2. Look for "Customize your pins" link (top right of the pinned section)
3. If you don't see it, you may need to click the gear icon
4. Select up to 6 repositories
5. Drag to reorder (most important first)
6. Click "Save pins"

**Can't find it?**
You need at least a few public repositories before the option appears.

**What can you pin?**
- Your own repositories
- Forks (if you've contributed meaningfully)
- Gists (code snippets)

sections.heading: What to Pin: Strategic Selection
sections.content:
**The ideal 6-pin strategy:**

| Slot | What to Pin | Example |
|------|-------------|--------|
| 1 | Best overall project | Full-stack app with great README |
| 2 | Most relevant to target jobs | E-commerce if applying for e-commerce roles |
| 3 | Different tech stack | Python project if others are JavaScript |
| 4 | Something unique | Browser extension, CLI tool, game |
| 5 | Collaborative/Open source | PR to popular repo or team project |
| 6 | Technical depth | Algorithm solutions or system design |

**What NOT to pin:**

‚ùå `tutorial-follow-along` - Obviously not original work
‚ùå `my-first-react-app` - Screams beginner
‚ùå Forked repos with 0 changes
‚ùå Projects with no README
‚ùå Incomplete/broken projects
‚ùå Old projects with outdated tech

sections.heading: Optimizing Repository Descriptions
sections.content:
Each pinned repo shows a description. Make them count.

**Edit the description:**
1. Go to the repository
2. Click the gear icon next to "About" (top right)
3. Edit Description (max ~100 chars)
4. Add Topics/Tags
5. Add Website URL (if deployed)

**Bad vs Good descriptions:**

‚ùå "A project I made"
‚úÖ "Full-stack recipe app | React, Node, PostgreSQL | 5K+ recipes"

‚ùå "React app"
‚úÖ "E-commerce platform with Stripe payments and real-time inventory"

‚ùå "Todo list"
‚úÖ "Drag-and-drop task manager with calendar sync and reminders"

**Formula:** `[What it is] | [Key tech] | [Impressive number or feature]`

sections.heading: Repo Topics: Free Keywords
sections.content:
Topics are tags that appear on your repository. They help with discovery AND show tech at a glance.

**How to add topics:**
1. Go to repository ‚Üí About (gear icon)
2. Add topics in the "Topics" field
3. Use relevant technology names

**Good topics for a React app:**
```
react typescript tailwindcss nodejs postgresql 
full-stack authentication crud-application
```

**Topics that help:**
- Technology names (react, python, django)
- Project type (full-stack, api, cli, chrome-extension)
- Skills demonstrated (authentication, real-time, responsive)

**Topics appear as clickable badges on your repo card.**

sections.heading: Maintaining Your Pinned Projects
sections.content:
Pinned projects need ongoing attention:

**Monthly checks:**
- [ ] Is the live demo still working?
- [ ] Are there security vulnerabilities to fix?
- [ ] Is the README still accurate?
- [ ] Would I still be proud of this code?

**When to swap out pinned projects:**
- You finish something better
- You're targeting different job types
- The project feels outdated
- You've grown and it no longer represents your skill level

**Archiving old projects:**
When you unpin an old project:
1. Go to Settings ‚Üí General
2. Scroll to "Danger Zone"
3. Click "Archive this repository"

This marks it as read-only and shows it's intentionally complete (not abandoned).

**Pro tip:** Screenshot your pinned repos view. Look at it like a recruiter would. What impression does it give in 5 seconds?

keyTakeaways: Pin your 6 best, most relevant projects‚Äîthey get 90% of recruiter attention
Order matters: best project first, relevant projects second
Optimize descriptions: [What] | [Tech] | [Impressive detail]
Add topics to each repo for extra visibility and credibility
Review and update pinned projects monthly

contribution-activity.title: Contribution Graphs & Activity
contribution-activity.intro: The green contribution graph tells a story about how active you are as a developer. Here's what recruiters look for and how to build healthy activity.

sections.heading: What Recruiters See
sections.content:
Your contribution graph shows:
- **Frequency:** How often you code
- **Consistency:** Regular activity vs. sporadic bursts
- **Recency:** When was your last contribution

**What they're actually looking for:**

‚úÖ Recent activity (last 2-4 weeks)
‚úÖ Some consistency (doesn't need to be daily)
‚úÖ Evidence you actually code

‚ùå NOT looking for:
- Perfect daily streaks
- Massive green walls
- Contributions every single day

**Real talk:** A moderately active graph with recent commits beats an impressive historical graph with nothing recent.

sections.heading: What Counts as a Contribution
sections.content:
**These count as contributions:**
- ‚úÖ Commits to a repo's default branch (main/master)
- ‚úÖ Opening an issue
- ‚úÖ Opening a pull request
- ‚úÖ Reviewing a pull request
- ‚úÖ Co-authoring a commit

**These DON'T count:**
- ‚ùå Commits to non-default branches
- ‚ùå Commits in forks (unless merged)
- ‚ùå Commits where your email doesn't match GitHub

**Common problem:** Commits not showing up?

Check your git config:
```bash
git config --global user.email
```

This email must match your GitHub email. If not:
```bash
git config --global user.email "your-github-email@example.com"
```

sections.heading: Building Healthy Activity
sections.content:
**Don't game the system. Build real activity:**

**Good habits:**
- Work on personal projects regularly (even 30 min/week)
- Make meaningful commits when you code
- Contribute to open source occasionally
- Create repos for learning (tutorials are fine)

**Bad habits:**
- Empty commits just for green squares
- Automated commit tools
- One massive commit then months of nothing

**If your graph is empty, start here:**

**Week 1-2:** Create a new project, commit progress daily
**Week 3-4:** Continue building, add documentation
**Week 5+:** Maintain with weekly commits, start something new

**Realistic expectations:**
- Few commits per week = healthy
- Gaps are normal (vacations, busy periods)
- Recent activity > historical activity

sections.heading: Activity Beyond Code
sections.content:
Your GitHub activity includes more than just commits:

**Issues:**
- Report bugs in tools you use
- Suggest features thoughtfully
- Help answer questions

**Example issue contribution:**
> Found a bug in popular-library? File an issue with:
> - Clear title
> - Steps to reproduce
> - Expected vs actual behavior
> - Your environment details

**Pull Requests (start easy):**
- Fix typos in documentation
- Look for "good first issue" labels
- Update outdated examples

**Finding opportunities:**
```
https://github.com/search?q=label%3A%22good+first+issue%22&type=issues
```

This shows all repos with beginner-friendly issues.

sections.heading: Private Contributions
sections.content:
Working on private repos (job, client work)? You can still show activity.

**Enable private contributions:**
1. Go to Settings ‚Üí Profile
2. Find "Contributions"
3. Check "Include private contributions on my profile"

**What this does:**
- Shows contribution squares for private repo activity
- Doesn't reveal the repo names or content
- Just shows you're actively coding

**Why use this:**
- If your job involves private repos
- If you have client projects
- If most of your real coding is private

**Note:** Only works for private repos you own or have push access to.

resources.title: Viewing Contributions on Your Profile
resources.description: Understanding what counts as a contribution

resources.title: First Contributions
resources.description: Beginner-friendly guide to making your first open source contribution

keyTakeaways: Recruiters check for recent, consistent activity‚Äînot perfect daily streaks
Make sure your git email matches your GitHub email
Build real activity through projects and open source, not fake commits
Issues and PRs count as contributions too‚Äînot just code
Enable private contributions if you work on non-public repos

portfolio-integration.title: GitHub as Part of Your Portfolio
portfolio-integration.intro: GitHub doesn't exist in isolation. It's one piece of your professional presence, alongside your resume, LinkedIn, and portfolio website. Here's how to integrate them effectively.

sections.heading: The Recruiter's Journey
sections.content:
Here's how recruiters typically navigate your online presence:

```
Resume ‚Üí LinkedIn ‚Üí GitHub ‚Üí Portfolio ‚Üí Decision
```

**At each step, they're asking:**

| Platform | Question |
|----------|----------|
| Resume | "Does this person have the right experience?" |
| LinkedIn | "Is this a real person? What's their full history?" |
| GitHub | "Can they actually code? Do they have projects?" |
| Portfolio | "What's the quality of their work?" |

**If any platform contradicts another, it raises red flags:**
- Resume says "5 years React" but GitHub shows only Python projects
- LinkedIn says "Senior" but GitHub shows only tutorial follow-alongs
- Portfolio shows polished work but GitHub has no code

**Your goal:** Consistent story across all platforms.

sections.heading: GitHub on Your Resume
sections.content:
**Placement:** Header, alongside email and LinkedIn

```
Jane Developer
jane@email.com | linkedin.com/in/janedev | github.com/janedev | janedev.com
```

**When listing projects:**

```
Recipe Discovery App                                    github.com/janedev/mince
Full-stack app helping users find recipes by ingredients | React, Node.js, PostgreSQL
- Built search feature handling 5,000+ recipes with <100ms response time
- Implemented JWT auth with password reset flow
- Deployed to Vercel with 99.9% uptime
```

**Link directly to specific repos** when discussing projects. Don't make recruiters hunt.

**Before sharing your resume:** Click every GitHub link to ensure:
- The repo exists
- The README is complete
- The project actually works

sections.heading: GitHub and LinkedIn Integration
sections.content:
**On LinkedIn, add your GitHub:**
1. Profile ‚Üí Contact Info ‚Üí Edit
2. Add Website ‚Üí GitHub Profile
3. Choose "Portfolio" or "Company Website" as type

**In LinkedIn Experience/Projects sections:**
```
Mince - Recipe Discovery App

Full-stack application helping home cooks find recipes 
based on ingredients they have.

Built with: React, Node.js, PostgreSQL
Live: mince-recipes.vercel.app
Code: github.com/janedev/mince
```

**Consistency checklist:**
- [ ] Same profile photo (or clearly same person)
- [ ] Same job titles and dates
- [ ] Same technologies highlighted
- [ ] Same projects mentioned
- [ ] Bio messaging aligns

sections.heading: Portfolio Website Integration
sections.content:
Your portfolio and GitHub complement each other:

| Portfolio Shows | GitHub Shows |
|-----------------|---------------|
| Polished screenshots | Actual code |
| User experience focus | Technical implementation |
| Case studies and process | Commit history and decisions |
| Design thinking | Code quality |

**On your portfolio, for each project:**

```markdown
## Mince - Recipe Discovery App

[Screenshot gallery]

[Case study: the problem, solution, my role]

[Live Demo](https://mince.vercel.app) | [View Code](https://github.com/janedev/mince)
```

**On GitHub, link back:**
```markdown
## Mince

![Screenshot](./screenshot.png)

For detailed case study and additional screenshots, 
visit my portfolio: [janedev.com/projects/mince](url)
```

**They're complementary, not redundant.** Each adds value the other can't.

sections.heading: Keeping Everything in Sync
sections.content:
**When you complete a new project:**

1. ‚úÖ Push to GitHub with complete README
2. ‚úÖ Add to portfolio with screenshots/case study
3. ‚úÖ Update LinkedIn projects section
4. ‚úÖ Update resume if it's a highlight

**When you change jobs/roles:**

1. ‚úÖ Update LinkedIn first
2. ‚úÖ Update GitHub bio if relevant
3. ‚úÖ Update resume
4. ‚úÖ Review pinned repos for relevance

**Monthly maintenance:**

- [ ] All live demos still working?
- [ ] GitHub pinned repos still best choices?
- [ ] Any new skills to add to bio/profile?
- [ ] Resume reflects latest projects?

**Quarterly deep review:**

- [ ] Full consistency check across all platforms
- [ ] Remove/archive outdated projects
- [ ] Update all bios and descriptions
- [ ] Ensure all links work

**Set a calendar reminder.** It takes 30 minutes quarterly to keep everything sharp.

keyTakeaways: Recruiters cross-reference resume, LinkedIn, GitHub, and portfolio‚Äîbe consistent
Link directly to GitHub repos when mentioning projects on resume
Use LinkedIn to add GitHub as a website in your contact info
Portfolio shows polish, GitHub shows code‚Äîlink them to each other
Set monthly/quarterly reminders to keep all platforms in sync
